>>9576005
I'm seeing a lot of healthy sales there. Yes it's not PS1 level but it's not bad at all for a system that only had an install base of about 6 Million. That's also only Famitsu Data. So that only tracks if the game made weekly charts and only tracks for how long they were on the carts.

We do know that worldwide Sega sold about 80 Million Saturn games, and about 2/3 of the worldwide install base was in Japan. We also know that the charts only show sales for about 430 games and the Saturn's Japanese library was over 1000 games. So if 2/3 of those 80 Million were in Japan that would be about 53 million games sold, and the Famitsu charts only account for about 35 Million. So there's almost 20 Million games sold and another 600 games released not reflected in those charts.

I think the main thing here is you see a few killer apps on Saturn, but then the sales spread out because you had a pretty wide variety of games. Third party games are also actually selling at a respectable level for the install base. If you want to see bad sales, look at the N64. Sure it has decent first party sales, but it completely goes off a cliff after the top 20. A lot of third parties had games that sold more copies on Saturn than their entire output on N64.

>>9574470
Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

this was the game where they really figured things out. previous entries in the series always felt middling to me, but this one felt like a complete package in a way that no other RTS had since BW. gameplay is very refined and well-balanced despite having an enourmous number of gameplay mechanics, and the audio-visual design is excellent. frankly, i can't think of much to criticize. it's always been puzzling to me that this game doesn't have more fans when it effectively brought C&C into the HD era with few blemishes, and even fixed a lot of what was broken. maybe it suffered from series fatigue and coming out during a time when the RTS genre was about to die, but you'd think the hardcore fanbase would still love it, and yet, there's just nothing there. very unfortunate, it's one of the best games in the genre for sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9580257
There isn't that much of an interconnected story, but it can still help to play them in order. 1 and 2 are basically prototypes regardless of what one vocal autist might tell you. A Link to the past is pretty much the beginning of the series as we know it today and for many still the best in the series, very fast and accessible, so the perfect entry point

Honestly, the other 2D Zeldas aren't quite as flawless and a bit too infested with puzzles and obstacles, therefore:
1) If you really, really love A Link to the Past and can't get enough of the formula, try Link's Awakening next
2) If you, what's more likely, dig ALTTP but feel satiated by it and maybe even put it on the back burner, start with 3D Zelda, namely Ocarina of Time
After OoT, you should try WW next
MM is great, but you should give OoT due time to sink in before playing such a derivative game. MM is offputting to some but the perfect Zelda to play when you're done with the rest and yearning for something distinct yet raw and unpolished (made in a year). You could also play it after WW if curious about the timeline where Link doesn't lose to Ganon and Hyrule doesn't get flooded (same timeline as TP)

After WW, you could already go by release order of the main games (WW, TP, SS, BOTW) and ignore the handheld games for the time being
However, there is no ideal way to play SS. The Wiimote controls are very fun, but of course require the respective hardware and commitment. The new pad controls in the remaster work but are far from ideal. It might have the best village in the series with a lot of optional content, but the main quest actually isn't great. It lacks a real overworld and turns into a puzzle orgy similar to new 2D Zeldas (same director as MC)
I would suggest skipping SS and watching the cutscenes on Youtube if you don't love the idea of motion sword fighting

Then it's BotW time

Generally, play other action adventures/RPGs before playing OoT to realize how ahead of its time it was

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The issue with the music is not the music files. The GCN would require you to code an audio engine to feed the audio to the GCN's sound chip inside the GPU. Sega was either unwilling or unable in time to license someone else's audio engine, so they made their own for the GCN, and it turned out pretty terrible. In a lot of sixth gen games, you'll see the Bink Video logo and copyright notice at the beginning of the game, that means they probably licensed parts of their audio engine from Bink. Sega probably didin't feel like paying the money for that. In order to mod the game with a different audio engine, you'd need the game's source code.

>>9576992
I have no idea what exactly this CRT is, but since it's widescreen I'm also assuming it's an HDCRT. Being widescreen isn't a big deal at all since you can still run 4:3 content in 4:3 mode. But if it's HD, that can cause some issues since it's digital and needs to upscale and/or deinterlace the image. So it won't look quite the same as a standard def CRT TV (ie, no scanlines) and there might be some input lag. Again, assuming it's HD. But also this would make it one of the best solutions for 480p stuff like on wii/gamecube/xbox and even playing 360/PS3 games in 1080i if you're into that (and the games support it)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9577235
With CRTs, the main specs are things like size (obviously), TV line count (higher = sharper image, lower = softer), and what inputs it has. But honestly all that is secondary compared to just the overall condition of the TV itself. These are old shitboxes, many have taken a beating, have fucked up calibration now, have been used for so long that the tube is worn out or has burn in, etc. And all those things need to be assessed on an individual basis. Is the tube dim and worn-out or burnt-in? Is the screen geometry totally fucked up? Can't really know without seeing yourself, I'm afraid.

>>9577328
>i have heard that calibration can be a bitch, any way to at least get an idea of how badly a tube isn't calibrated
test patterns. An easy one to use is the 240p Test Suite, which you can run from a flashcart or a CD on a number of different consoles

Now, chances are the geometry is PROBABLY good enough, but there's a chance that it's not and you could go down a rabbit hole of service menu tweaks, magnetic strips on the back of the tube, yolk adjustments, recapping daughterboards, etc.

>>9576950
I have several CRTs, ranging from PVMs of different sizes, arcade monitors, PC monitors, the works. I love the things. Let me offer some advice:

1) If I had to start collecting now, I would NOT do it. I'm simply priced out. The market is ridiculous now, and everything is overpriced to hell and back. But I get it: It's exactly like that with any other market where the supply is fixed and ever decreasing: Prices are gonna get higher. If you think you really want a CRT, then the best time to buy is always right now.

2) I see you're talking about this as an investment. Personally, I think CRTs are NOT good investments. You should only consider them if you have tons of free space and are really interested in multiple aspects of the technology.

3) It would be good if you have some knowledge of electronics. These things are not getting any younger and sooner than later you will have to fix them.

A (very) reasonable, sensible alternative is a good scaler combined with a low lag LCD, or even a projector if you're interested in huge screens. Feel free to reply if you have any follow-up questions. Have a good whatever it is in your timezone.

If you're anywhere close to a city, facebook marketplace, craigslist, offer up, literally any locals listings will have some. If you're in a remote area you might have to travel a bit, or just be patient and take a week or two checking occasionally until one pops up, but really they're easy to find.

They come in all sizes. Many late consumer ones were miniaturized to the point they were designed for kitchens and other secondary spaces, these ones are perfect if you're constrained by space.

I'd say keep an eye out for one that has component if you want ps2, ps2 over component looks gorgeous. >>9578573
When you first visit Kakariko Village and talk to the foreman, he mentions having a good-for-nothing son that sits around doing nothing all day. When you talk to the blue dude at night, he's just sitting around like a hobo in the exact same spot the foreman is during the day and mentions that his father and mother are disgusting. Thus the game is hinting he's the foreman's son. He leaves behind a saw, which a carpenter might use, which taken together with the heavy hint at the foreman being his father leads to the obvious conclusion that you might want to try taking it to him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Time Splitters (only on Game Cube)
>Time Splitters 2
>Quake 3 : Arena
>Half-Life : Decay (only on Playstation 2)
>Serious Sam : The First Encounter
>Serious Sam : The Second Encounter
>Metroid Prime (only on Gamecube )
>Medal Of Honor : Frontline
>Unreal Championship
>007 : Nightfire
These were the good games which looked modern and were on PS2, XBox, and Gamecube between 2000 to 2002. Certainly worthy competitors in the market (Metroid Prime maybe not aiming for the exact same market segments), but with the edge of splitscreen and online multiplayer, together with overall being a good game with good presentation, marketed strongly, I don't think there's any wonder why it did quite well for itself.

However, people forget that if you wanted a first person shooter on XBox, that Halo was the ONLY one there until 2002, where you would see a couple of middling games until roughly about a year after Halo's launch, where you'd finally see some good games on the console like Unreal Championship, Serious Sam, Timesplitters 2, etc. Thus, Halo had basically an unchallenged share of the market for a time, where its reputation did it well against middling or nonexistent competition on its home turf, letting it establish itself pretty well, with the PC port not coming until 2003, and which wasn't quite great, so if you were interested in Halo you probably wanted to get it on XBox. This would help set the stage for Halo 2 in 2004, which was a real barnburner, selling over two million units on its release day, and which had a popular and enduring multiplayer scene.

tl;dr it was a good game which in some aspects had limited competition, with a series which kept growing in popularity as it went.

The game itself is painfully derivative; its sole contribution to the genre was making analog control scheme standard for console shooters. In every other way, Halo ranges from mediocre to outright bad. Let's talk about some of Halo's "innovations"...
>game begins with superhuman cyborg badass running away from every enemy he sees while human soldiers defend him, until he can find a general that gives him a weapon (and says he doesn't keep it loaded, even though he does. because uhhh... no reason at all.)
>first real level drops you into a wide open environment with absolutely 100% fuck all nothing to find, where you'll skirmish with a handful of small enemy groups and then drive a buggy and then it's over
>later levels are either most of the first few levels played in reverse, or the library, where you walk through endless blue corridors shooting the shittiest enemy ever designed for a video game for 2 hours
>every weapon is complete dogshit and outclassed in almost every way by the very first weapon you find. in fact, the only reason to ever use any other weapon is when you have no pistol ammo. at best, you might use the rocket launcher or sniper a few times in very circumstantial instances.
>no online multiplayer except on PC (which was botched), they seriously expected people to play 3-4 person splitscreen on giant empty as fuck maps unless they could convince a dozen fat retards to come to their house and play LAN (which 99% of players never did despite what anyone tells you)

Then, when a later newbie outsider takes interest in the game and tries it out, they find themselves stomped by the elite old guard who know game and meta like the back of their own hand and have 10+ years of well reinforced neural pathways, which can make these scenes feel impenetrable. Less apparent in games where there's other game modes besides deathmatch and team play, but it's still easy to feel like a fifth wheel in co-op multiplayer when the experienced players do all the work while you're still trying to figure out what you're doing and how to approach it.

It's not really so much the competitive, and the old competitive players from the height of the game may very well still be able to trounce the rest of the playerbase once they readapt to the game or/and derust their gaming skills, depending on where they went in life.

>>9579129
Grenade buttons weren't invented by Halo, but that doesn't mean that Halo didn't have a part in popularizing them. There's many cases where an aspect may get credited to something even if it wasn't actually the first game to ever do it, often it's because the game in question did it both in a good way, and the game sold well, making a good and visible example.
You can look at FPS as a whole for this, Wolfenstein 3D gets touted as the original first person shooter, but it isn't true, aside from iD themselves having made the Catacomb 3D and Hovertank 3D games back when they were still the Gamer's Edge division at Softdisk magazine, there's simple first person shooting games on arcades and even computers and consoles which predate that.

What Wolfenstein 3D does though is put the player in a 3D space with textured walls, where they can move freely, and there's a focus on FAST gameplay, no fiddling with any stats or inventory, it's just shooting the gnutzis, avoiding getting shot as much as you can, while managing your resources and finding the exit to the next level (which may involve up to two different keys), finding treasures and secrets confers benefits of extra lives and putting yourself on your own personal scoreboard.
The gameplay is perhaps slightly too simple (hence being quickly overshadowed by Doom, which hits a fantastic balance), but more importantly it was a fast and widely available first person action game unlike any other.
Thus, it gets credit for assembling this into the very base formula that came to change the world.

Of course, nothing Halo does actually REVOLUTIONIZES anything, huge hits had done it all before, and it didn't reinvent grenade buttons, games like Team Fortress Classic already implemented those well, but it was one of those games which made the concept really take off because it was a fairly big commercial and critical hit which implemented the mechanic well and made it a prominent feature of its popular multiplayer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Halo was average at best. People thought it was amazing because they were young and impressionable when Microsoft's marketing machine kicked into overdrive to move units on the x-box, since it was the 'flagship' title.

I've played many hundreds of hours of those games in a social setting (split screen, LAN, XBL and Xlink). Why did I play so many hours on an average game? Because it was a good way to catch up with friends and let off some steam, since it geared as a party game, so people that weren't that skilled could still join and have fun.

In the group of course there were three fanboys that played even more than me, their explanations as to why it's "so awesome":

>it doesn't do everything well, but it puts together different things well
Perhaps the most honest answer, he can't point at anything in particular, he's played enough games to know Halo didn't invent much new, but likes that there isn't any major annoyances in integrating all the different systems (from controls to game balance).

>the AI
This is because the levels were heavily scripted, so for example someone might say "wow that elite took cover behind this corner there when it's shields were down, that was clever" - players don't know that Bungie just added these places into the terrain. Another level where you're on the beach, where grunts and jackals "fall back" because you shot the elite, there is actually a zone on the beach where they can retreat to baked into the game.

>the short time to kill, recharging shields/health
Honestly, I was never a huge fan of this concept but I think Halo 1 nailed it the best with the longer recharge time and and needing to venture to health packs. When they shortened the timer and fast regenerating health, for Halo 2 and beyond, it made the dynamic even worse (encourages people to just hide out of the action).

I don't care much for regenerating health, I find it's usually a crutch for not wanting to do better level design, but grenades being a quick button instead of its own defined weapon to manually switch to is just fucking practical and makes grenades more viable and fun. With a button I can just make a grenade throw and it automatically returns me to my weapon afterwards, that's smooth and I don't need to come to a halt, you can make the gameplay faster for it, and in return increase the challenge for the player to match their abilities.

In Half-Life, I find myself not using hand grenades all that often because that requires that I stop shooting what I'm using now and switching to another weapon, manually throwing it, and then switching back. Because of that, in the heat of combat I basically never ever use them because I don't want to let up the pressure, whereas I gladly use the grenade launcher altfire because it's very conveniently attached to my machinegun (and it also detonates on impact).
The role I end up using them for (aside from maybe demolition or setting off tripmines from around a corner), is if I have the drop on an enemy, in which case one or two grenades are my opening before lay down fire. This is useful, but more occasionally, and the grunts tend to avoid it, which in itself isn't bad, it's nice that different enemies require differing tactics and approaches, that's good, but it makes the already limited grenades still more limited.

If I instead chuck one with a dedicated press, I could maybe use it when in actual combat with the grunts, if nothing else to flush them out or suppress them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563351
>are you sure? i saw one of these at pontins in prestatyn in late 90s/early 00s. If they only made 50 it's hard to imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
No one knows the exact number for sure. Literally anyone with $250,000 to blow could have ordered a Ridge Racer Full Scale from Namco between 1993 and 1998. I'm not saying only 50 units were made. All I know is that I could only confirm around 50 with my research but more could have been made. It would not surprise me if more were manufactured.

Arcade collectors on forums like to say that only around 20 ridge racer full scale units were ever made, and pretend it was some sort of super rare machine. Which is complete bullshit. Namco would not invest millions into tooling an entire arcade factory and only make 20 units. They aren't Sega. Namco is actually well known for being financially responsible. It would not surprise me if 100 or 200 were made. I've talked to people that claim they saw Ridge Racer Full Scale in malls, movie theater lobbies, big arcades, theme parks, beach resorts, airports, etc.

>imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
Your holiday camp probably bought them used at a big discount. During the early 2000s, many arcades were closing down because the arcade market crashed and never recovered. Businesses were selling their arcade machines on eBay and several websites for super cheap. That includes Ridge Racer Full Scale. I remember seeing them for sale. You could have gotten it for cheap if you had a few thousand dollars back then. I'm guessing a few places picked up a Full Scale for cheap and got a couple more years of use out of it until the machine broke down and was scrapped. Sucks that no one saved even one working unit.

>>9564774
Arcade business owners paid huge sums of money for arcade cabinets with the promise that they will earn their investment back in 6 months and start earning profit. Ridge Racer Full Scale was no different.

An arcade owner could pay $200,000 for Ridge Racer Full Scale. Yes that's huge for an arcade. But they could charge $5 dollars per play. Let's assume when it first came out that 500 people per day played Ridge Racer Full Scale. That $2,500 dollars a day. That's about $75,000 a month. That's $450,000 in 6 months. That's $900,000 in 1 year. It's already more than paid for itself.

I know you think these numbers are silly and absurd. But you don't understand. The 80s and 90s were a different time. Arcades were incredibly popular back then. A cultural phenomenon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564825
Ah...these ski machines. These things used to be everywhere. There aren't many "old school" Namco or Sega ski arcade machines like Super Alpine racer around anymore in arcades.

These machines saw a lot of abuse. People were very rough on the machines and the foot mechanisms were prone to breaking without periodic maintenance. People slamming their whole body weight left and right would eventually cause something to break. Many of these machines would break down as years passed.

The rear projection screens also were an issue as time passed. The bulbs inside needed to be replaced after a certain amount of hours of use. The bulbs cost money, and arcade owners don't want to invest money in keeping the screen running. Especially when LCD technology is now available.

They are also very bulky. If you do see a ski machine in arcades, it's probably a new one made Raw Thrills.

I'm not saying these old school Namco or a Sega Ski Machines are rare to find...Or that they worth a lot of money. They are out there and You could definitely find one for sale if you want on some websites. But shipping is expensive and it will probably need some sort of maintenance done.

Many arcade owners simply got rid of them after several years rather than continue maintaining them.

>>9572970
So the actual scope on the gun had a small display inside sniper rifle scope that showed a magnified in detailed version of what you were looking at in relation to where you pointed the gun on the screen for more precise shots because the main screen had a large wide field of view of the area for you to look for targets but the targets were extremely small and quite often too far away to really get a proper look at. There is however an operator setting to show the scope's magnified vision on the display in the upper left or upper right corner of the main screen and you could play that way I guess but it sort of detracts from the experience a little bit of feeling like you're a sniper. I'm not sure how the console ports of the Silent Scope games were, I think maybe console ports had a toggle button to show the magnification temporarily when need with a button toggle or maybe it had a locking on feature.

There are downsides to a flat cover with freeplay.

From interviews with other arcade owners.

1. Some people hog machines, and refuse to let others play.

3. Machines gets worn out much faster and need more maintenance.

>>9580696
I have to say, sometimes it feels like I'm the only one that cares at all about Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six (1992/NES) as it rarely gets mentioned and, when it does, it's usually to use it as an example of subpar Spider-Man video games. I'm not going to pretend that I don't know why that's the case, the control is somewhat awkward, though nothing one can't get used to with time, and it's clunky for 1992 standards, even though most of the NES library is clunky too, but the main issue that it had, which was common back then, is that it felt like a video game with Spider-Man in it, instead of a Spider-Man video game. Also, it takes only 15min to complete it, and the level design really nosedives in its 2nd half, not only that, but the OST literally has 2 tracks, graphics aren't that good for a 1992 NES release, and the story/presentation are barely there... still, it plays fine and once you get used to it, it can be fun, especially in the 1st half where level design is interesting too, more vertical and with items to collect. I also love how enemies explode when defeated, sound effects are satisfying. I still have a lot of nostalgia for this.

posts.name: Anonymous

>Also, it takes only 15min to complete it, and
if you're watching TAS videos it is, realistically something a bit more than an hour to beat. While not one of the harder NES games, it's also not a cakewalk the way something like Wacky Races is.

>>9581027
Oh, I apologize, the way I said it in my post really wasn't ideal, what I meant to say was that, once you know all of the proper strategies for getting past everything safely, it's a 15min run to complete it, which is probably why you only have 1 life and 1 continue, 2 lives pretty much, since using the continue takes you back to the last checkpoint instead of the start of the level, well, getting back to what I was saying, they saw that it was too short and padded it out by giving you few tries and some cheap moments, to beat it for the 1st time it'll take a while, lots of trial and error with you getting sent back to the title screen often, but when you figure out a strategy for each and every one of the cheaper parts of the levels, it's quite short. What gave me the most trouble were the bosses, the cheap enemy that can take all of your health quickly in Mysterio's level and the main enemy in Hobgoblin's level, but eventually I figured out the best strategy for all of them. One thing that helps is knowing when to hold the punch button to do more damage, like in Sandman's boss fight, or just tapping it, in Mysterio's boss fight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9581107
I don't doubt that it could've been the case, but the evidence you've suggested can be explained really.

>that stage in the dark where you fight zombie-like enemies with sickles
It can be excused by it being Mysterio's level, a villain that's all about illusions, who worked in films before being a villain.

>woods stage with axe-throwing guys
According to the manual they're trolls that throw clubs... so it is indeed odd for Spider-Man, but I believe the woods might be an attempt at Central Park or something.

>last stage which takes place a castle (why the fuck Doc Ock resides in a castle with his portraits on the walls? was that in the comic?)
In the 1st ever comic with the Sinister Six, Amazing Spider-Man Annual #1, Doc Ock has a castle, and it's where he fights Spider-Man, as odd as that may sound it really did happen.

>>9581325
If I had to rank Meteor's past arranges, I would go SS > WW > PP > QQ > TT > CC >>> MM. Metallic Madness feels like a subdued version of the present version and overall feels weaker compared to the rest of the set, except for maybe the power drill whirring in the background. Stardust Speedway and Palmtree Panic give some really cozy and relaxing vibes, while Wacky Workbench makes me want to dance a little, and the rest have this melancholy feel to them, they really establish a strong atmosphere.

As for your question, I don't know. I reckon they figured the infeasibility of replacing the past tracks early in development and never bothered creating tracks for them, and if they did, they're probably long discarded by now.

If you're still craving Sonic CD music, here's some more past arranges. These ones take more creative liberties than Meteor's.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9580883
Eh, I sense some bitter bias here. Yes, its true that NOA and NOE during the NES years often had a bias against overt themes regarding themes and symbols of many IRL faiths and/or religions as per their pre-ESRB political correctness game censorship guidelines, which also forbade references to alcohol, illicit drug use, and, most on-screen bloodshed. However, as much as there are references to Christianity here and there, especially in the early years of the franchise, that the Cross is not an exclusively Christian symbol, just as the Six-pointed star is not exclusive to Judaism. True, the special book in the early Zelda games is literally called a "Bible", and cross imagery in a number of areas, the bulk of them in the early titles. But what makes you so damn sure that the word "Shimpu" is specifically meant to mean a Christian Priest? How fluent in Japanese are you, really? The language is often vague, its written form (aside from Kanji, which acts somewhat more like Chinese does) is a syllabary, is more reader dependent in its structure than any of the languages of Europe, and those of the Indian subcontinent, and Southeast Asia. I also add that even in the pre-Majora's mask era of LOZ, there are also other lore and folkloric beings from different parts of the world present. Fairies (Celtic and Germanic Lore) can be found in every game in the series. The Master Sword in Link to the past/Triforce of the Gods is very much reminiscent of Celtic Arthurian legend and lore. The swimming fish that raise their heads out of the water to make ranged magic ball attacks found in LOZ1 and ALTTP/Triforce of the Gods are more Japanese Kappa-inspired. Not sure about the Peahat enemies, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I beat both versions, it's actually quite amazing how literally EVERYTHING was reskinned, not just the protagonist. Well, almost everything, in the Japanese version each boss has a different design, but in Yo Noid! you get the same grey boss which is the same visual as the protagonist anyway....

Also there are a couple of level design changes, most notably one of the secret mini game that serves as a warp point is unreachable in Yo Noid!, despite the warp point still existing (I checked the RAM map), the platform to reach it is missing.
Also felt like the JPN version had slighlty better hit detection but I'm not sure. Possibly it's just the size of sprites and objects ended up not quite matching in Yo Noid.

Anyway, okay game(s) overall but disappointing for a Capcom game. The worst thing about it is how you have to constantly hit air everywhere you go in order to find the precious p-ups which are absolutely necessary for the boss mini games.

It's a very accomplished work of set-piece adventuring.
There's a really nice blend of giving the player agency but not too much space so the main thrust of the story does not lose momentum. It never feels like there's a dull moment or it devolves into an empty grind which was more or less the norm for JRPGs of the era.

On top of that all the characters, locations and moments are very memorable.

I'd say it's a pinnacle of a "guided JRPG".

It's overrated for a few reasons:
1) it does some unique/interesting things that make people perceive it to be better than it actually is
2) 90's jrpgs are massively overrated... mostly because people evaluate them in the context of their time instead of realistically comparing them against all games across all time. They also get a pass for a lot of things just due to the storyline and anime feel.
3) Games that reached mainstream in pre 2005 days get elevated to some untouchable status, but if you actually play other games from the same time period or even modern indie games you'll see that it's not that unique.

With that being said, it's a good game. Not life changing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562815
in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563087

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.
Bil Herd claimed they had difficulty doping the wafers properly and applied too much dopant for the die size--this resulted in excessive conductivity and was visible on the die as "creeping crud" (his words). For contrast here's a section of an 8086 die. The transistors are dark purple from the dopant coating. What presumably happened with those TED chips was excess dopant oozing out onto the substrate.

p. sure the actual die size of those first 6502s was 6 micrometers. in one of their early press releases MOS were promising a die shrink soon. this was accomplished in late 1976 when they went to 5 micrometers. the initial 6502s also had a non-functional ROR instruction which was fixed in the 5 micrometer version.

posts.com: I think that's accurate. MOS used 6xxx P/Ns for chips using the original 5-6 um process, 7xxx for the faulty HMOS I process, and 8xxx for the "fixed" HMOS II chips.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9557841
As an EE, I say this has to be case-by-case. Throwing heat sinks around without reason can do more harm than good e.g. if they fall off and short the PCB.
Quality of IC manufacture, PCB/circuit design and tolerance to other part variation/failure are a few factors affecting IC life. True it is a waste of time for most instances, but a stoopid looking heat sink in the right place could help if a chip is poorly made, or could be subject to abnormal operating conditions. Any actual benefit, if any, will depend on the context

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9579143
Could be a subreddit he's pasting from. It is still better to run stuff not too hot; a chip's data sheet will state its maximum operating temperature and for the 5 um NMOS chips Commodore used this was about 70C. In typical operating use a VIC-II will probably reach about 40C but a sink will knock several degrees off of that. Keep in mind that 5 um was already an outdated process node by the early 80s and most chips had moved to smaller sizes by then. The C64C has 2 um chips that only get a little warm when running and are significantly more reliable. Only the 8580 SID still gets a bit hot as it retains a separate 9V line to operate its analog filters.

>>9579973
>All the SIDs I've seen dead were either from Power Supply problems or Joystick Port problems.
nah that's the CIAs that would get zapped from joystick port ESD. SIDs tend to get ESD damage from hot plugging cables or plugging them into a stereo amp although in most cases the analog filters get zapped rather than the core circuitry.

WDC sells new CIAs but they're a modernized CMOS version that doesn't behave exactly like the original NMOS 6522. also it lacks the RTC feature although that's no major loss.

>>9562853
HMOS is simply the name Intel came up with for the 3.5 um depletion mode process they developed for the 8086 and licensed to other manufacturers (initially tested on a DRAM chip prior to the 8086's introduction). It's really just NMOS with a smaller die size, nothing special about it. Using Intel's terminology, HMOS I was the original 3.5 um process, HMOS II was 2 um, and HMOS III was 1 um.

This is the actual one stop solution for emulation. Not FPGA memeshit, not mini console scalped bullshit, not original hardware which is difficult to store and can be expensive.

Power conservation matters for 24/7 servers. You will see a hit on the power bill running an old server or desktop like that. An RPi not so much.

A device that is on an hour or so a day will cause a marginal effect.

I used to run xeon servers at home. I scaled down to a nuc and virtualization. Then I scaled down again to a few RPis. I wouldn't suggest RPis for anything needing equivalent or greater than a modern laptop compute, because it isn't going to be enough. I would only use RPi for a low power always on solution.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9581076
>FFL1/2 better games?
I think so, so do most SaGa fans think as well. You'd only think the opposite if you want something traditional.
>I looked through some reviews for them, they are very mixed unlike FFL3 which gets mostly high ratings
Yeah, because FFLIII has experience points and levels were as FFLI and II doesn't have that system and went with different races with varying methods of character growth. To give two examples from the first game the only way to make humans stronger is to buy potions of HP, strength, and agility to upgrade their stats. Monsters on the other hand need to eat monster meat dropped from battles so they can transform into other monsters. Each monster form has their own stat spread which is fixed and skill set (includes battle skills along with elemental weakness and resistance skills). The thing with monster meat is that there is a possibility to transform into weaker monsters, but it is also possible to get absurdly strong transformations as well, but the path way through monster transformations isn't told either through the game manual or in game so it's up to the player to experiment.

>>9561908
>Alpha 3 and Darkstalkers 3 don't have to load up four characters at a time.
And? My point is that these ports are ok. What's yours? We settled for much less during the 16-bit generation so having A3 and D3 at home at this quality was great. Especially since Saturn versions stayed in Japan.
>The N64 with the expansion pak has 8MB of unified RAM.
Unified RAM doesn't help when texture cache is only 4kb and bottlenecks the whole system when it has to be explicitly asked to constantly fetch new data from RAM. PS1 texture cache on the other hand is an associative cache so it takes no CPU cycles to be updated and VRAM size is the only limit.
In short, N64 port of a Capcom fighting game can have arcade perfect animation stored in RAM but actually displaying it at real time would stall the whole thing.

Ok, since you guys continue to insist, let's check MK Trilogy closely.
First of all, MK games have simplistic backgrounds with many tiling and repeating elements. Compare this with CPS2 games that have more big and unique, sometimes animates objects in their backgrounds.
Next, the chatacters animations. MK Trilogy sprites are very thin and don't have much unique animations. SF Alpha games are kind of simple too but Darkstalkers and Marvel vs games have more elaborate attack animations that take a large chunk of screen (and VRAM). MK Trilogy being this lightweight on animations is pretty much confirmed by the PS1 version: it easily holds 4 unique characters for 2 on 2 combat in PS1 RAM - when one character is defeated the game doesn't stop to load the second one from the disc. No Capcom game manages to have four complete and unique characters in a single fight on PS1 because they take much more memory than Mortal Kombat ones.
N64 has more RAM and doesn't have to deal with loading from the disk at all, so it allows SIX unique characters in 3 on 3 combat. Great, right? But here's the deal: the animation quality is worse than in PS1 version. So while there are six characters in N64 RAM, even having only two of them on screen, N64 can't animate them as fast as PS1 version. This is barely a cart size issue - adding a couple of frames to each character standing idle animation would make them look a whole lot smoother and this takes a very little space of ROM. MKT ROM has a enough of padding (aka unused space) for this. Even without using the unused space they could just remove that fancy MK logo in flames title screen and shitty looking MK1 stages and add better animation instead. But they didn't because N64 can't run it as smooth anyway.

>>9562805
There are certainly no 1800 sprites in Mario Kart. It makes a heavy use of composed sprites, aka sprites made from separate elements. Car is animated separately, wheels are animated separately and superimposed over thr car sprite. And then finally the chracter sprite is added on top. Using dynamic palettes for car colors you may "construct" unique sprites for every racer. The sprites themselves are very nicely and smoothly animated but they are very small in size. And finally, the game doesn't run at 60 fps. It runs at 30 and it's enough to fetch needed data from VRAM to buffer. A 2D fighting game at 30 fps would be a big downgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9562805
>N64 could use the cart rom chip like RAM and stream data much faster than any optical media console on the market
And just to add to this, no cart based system actually does this. It still has to use RAM or different caches in between. The question is how fast can it fetch the data? Not to mention that many N64 games had to use compressed graphics so the system had to take the data from the cart, then uncompress it to RAM and only then it could use it. It wasn't free.
The system that operates very similar to what you describe is Neo Geo. I don't remember exact details but SNK didn't bother with ROM sizes and memory costs and used the biggest ones available because they could sell the carts at a big cost anyway. And then NG architecture allowed them to stream the graphics from ROM to RAM almost for free. N64 was built with different strengths in mind (fast 3D scene calculations) and it wasn't optimized to toss large sprites around with the same ease.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So CPS2 games use frame skipping to enable their turbo modes. The higher turbo mode the more frames are skipped.
But instead you could do this in reverse. You can run the gameplay logic at 60 fps internally while only displaying 50 fps sprite updates but stretching out the time the frame is on screen to make the gameplay speed still the "normal" speed*. This won't have much of an effect on the visual appearance of the game because sprites are often held on screen for multiple frames anyway so rarely will an important frame get skipped. It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**

There were other tricks used in the PS1 ports that should work here. Changing the hit sparks to 3d graphics is the first thing. The life bars could also be 3d. That's a little bit of memory savings. I think you could probably do something for the in-game timer to make it out of 3d graphics as well. Not numbers but maybe something like a two colored wheel that runs out.

*Tournament players would cry about the slowness but it is what it is.
**This would make occasional differences to the gameplay by having a move be one or two more frames of animation longer on screen resulting in something that would usually be safe on block to be punishable.

The information you describe is totally wrong.
Most cart consoles have memory-mapped ROM with RAM-like access timing. Sprite streaming is a common practice. Its easy to see it in Mario Kart Super Circuit, for example, by opening a VRAM viewer or tweaking the ROM timing in an emulator.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563434
>It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**
Thinking over it again the animations would be the same length but what you would do is repeat the same sprite as before or after the sprite you frame skipped over.

So if you were doing a 1/6 frame skip you'd skip every sixth frame and replace it with either the frame in front of it or behind it. You could make this alternate if you wanted, or come up with more elaborate plans.
I *think* this should result in a significant saving of resources without making too much of a hit on the gameplay since the arcade version is typically played in "Turbo" mode that employs a frame-skip. So players are used to that and accept it. But here instead of using the frame skip to increase gameplay speed you're keeping the same speed but saving resources to free up time for the N64 hardware to keep up.
Again, this does result in the game running in what in the arcade version is the slow "normal" speed option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Interesting thread that is probably related.
https://www.reddit.com/r/EmuDev/comments/ug5ere/about_texture_caches/

>I wrote a texture cache for an emulator many years ago when we were emulating Primal Rage on the Xbox. The total size of the textures were larger than the total amount of ram available on the Xbox so we compressed each texture using deflate and then loaded and unpacked them as they were needed. I used a simple linked list of textures and every time a texture was used it was moved to the head of the texture list. I used a map to quickly locate which textures were already unpacked in memory and which ones needed to be loaded from the CD. When a texture needed to be loaded, the last used texture (at the tail of the linked list) was discarded and the new texture was asynchronously loaded & unpacked and added to the head of the linked list.

From a real N64 developer

>We streamed audio and animation data off the cart during game play, we could have certainly gotten the audio streamed off CD and probbly some of the animation. But we'd have needed bigger internal buffers.

>Back to the original question, i was a pretty big limitation, as mentioned it wasn't a cache in the traditional sense it was an explicitly loaded block of memory that was the only place you could render from. It could not be updated mid triangle, so if you wanted a texture that wouldn'y fit, you were stuck with adding more tris and doing more explict loads, which generally led to poor performance.
What was worse was that enabling trilinear split the cache in half, so it was a 2K block of memory for the largest MipMap.

>It required thought and some understanding of the technical limitations on the art side to work around.

From reading this thread and some of the linked materials it is my understanding that one of the big bottlenecks is that the N64 texture cache is too small for a CPS2 16x16 and 32x32 tile size.

If each color value for each pixel is a byte then that's

16*16*3 = 768 bytes per tile.

32*32*3 = 3072 bytes per tile

4 KB = 4000 bytes

So the tiles will fit. Is it then just a question of speed moving textures in and out of cache?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561618

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571169
>From reading this thread and some of the linked materials it is my understanding that one of the big bottlenecks is that the N64 texture cache is too small
But a 2d game doesn't have to use polygons. The N64 has programmable "microcode"... meaning there is like an interface layer for using the hardware and this can be changed by the programmer, which was done in advanced games like those by Factor 5. There were some alternate microcodes provided by SGI including one for 2d. Anyway, the texture cache issue relates to the 3d rendering pipeline. An optimised 2d game with custom microcode would probably not have any issues at all relating to texture cache. For example, the framebuffer can be written to directly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571323
Any examples of an N64 game that you think might have used SGI's 2d microcode or a custom version made by the developers?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571323
Microcode relates to RSP not RDP. There's a lot of control over how your polygons get generated but not much how they get drawn.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571323
This is the biggest problem with any "can the N64..." topic. Nintendo was so draconian and there were very few Andy Gavins playing in that sandbox that we don't have a lot of examples of games that deviated from the norm set by Nintendo's own games. So a lot of it is theoretical with no examples to point to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571323
So for a 2D game the screen can be drawn without going through the cache? I don't fully understand how the system gets the image on screen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9572262
The point of texture cache is the renderer can access textures in cache as it is rendering, as in, on a per-polygon basis. So that's a process where it's iterating through geometry and applying textures as it goes and it is optimised for that. Quite a few games write to the frame buffer directly for HUD and menus. I'm sorry, I don't have an in-depth knowledge of the N64 architecture. The only way to know which games used which microcode would be to decompile them or to get that information from the developers themselves. AFAIK, no 2d N64 games have been decompiled (Paper Mario doesn't count, obviously). The N64 developer manual has been online for a while and this is the part that talks about microcode, https://ultra64.ca/files/documentation/online-manuals/functions_reference_manual_2.0i/ucode/microcode.html . The N64's graphic chip, SGI's "Reality Co-Procssor" is much more complicated than the hardware in prior consoles, where you were literally just writing background scroll values to hardware registers. SGI came from a very different world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The reason it's shown as a gameboy game is because while the original gameboy just has four shades of grey, later on there was a super gameboy cartridge which let you play your gameboy games on the your SNES. For those games, there is some extra data in there for it, so it could convert these four shades to colours. This is just like extra palette data and the palettes are predetermined from the SNES master palette, so you're just saying use palette 3 (which had four colours), rather than entirely custom palettes.

The game also included coloured sprites to fill up the rest of the screen (again using the palettes) like background decoration. These are still just regular game boy games because at the time there was no gameboy colour. When the gameboy colour did come out, it had a neat little trick where on startup, you could set the game to use one particular palette as the main palette for everything. And the gameboy colour also knew how to interpret the coloured palettes (if you left it on the default main one), so even in the original pokemon games, they switched to shades of blue or green for different areas, and switch to a palette with green for the health bars and so on.

I think the reason why Yellow's palette is different is because they weren't limited to the predefined ones in the super gameboy, so they could pick from a wider range of colours for the four different ones, and they went for more vibrant ones. One thing I never tried, but would be curious to, is if you played yellow on a super gameboy, would it 'fall back' to the same palettes as red and blue?

>>9573968
On top of being a critical hook to sell the game/store, giant robots were because Deus was a bioengineered weapon. The tools he created were biomechanics with further simplified ones being just mechanical. For a central part of the premise which really shouldn't be questioned because it's basically like questioning why rock music has a guitar in it, there is a reasonable enough explanation.
Why nanomachines show up should be obvious.
The significance of demihumans is likewise a critical part of the whole Deus plotline. In case you missed the entire last third of the game, it planned on using specifically-cultivated human stock selectively engineered so that it could be integrated into its body to revive itself. Demihumans were kind of like the proof of concept.
The pink Ewoks were a Star Wars reference. If the colony ship crashed on a planet with a functioning ecosystem it would make sense that there were natives. I'll agree that they added nothing and could easily have been removed, though.

>>9580681
No he's pretty much right.

Michael Kirkbride binged on mushrooms and locked himself in his apartment for a week to write the 36 lessons of Vivec. The 36 lessons are pretty convoluted and lean heavily into the idea that Vivec is trying to revise history as he goes, while also weathering the effects of time on a newly immortal being. This is the local Dark Elf religion, which is nominally-subservient to the Empire.

The Empire is a sort of fantasy hodgepodge of what the Roman Empire was at it's height. Both sides have HEAVILY propagandized their own mythology, and there is a ton of conflict between the Dark Elf nation and the pseudo-globalist culture of The Empire. There are a lot of different factions subdivided within those two groups, and they're being forced to deal with each other.

You get a lot of different sides to the issue through the factions. You have 2 temple factions, 3 fighting factions, 2 thief factions, 2 mage factions, and religiously-sanctioned assassin's guild all coming into conflict with one another, it's fucking crazy and you have to make multiple characters to experience it all since so much is mutually-exclusive. Nothing is particularly black-and-white either, it all comes down to personal choice.

The Main Quest focuses on Dagoth Ur, who is the most extreme, ultra-nationalist Dark Elf position, taken to the point of insanity, plague, and body horror, mixed with the lucidity of a powerful mysticism mage.

>>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

Some of these weird regional releases for the Sega Megadrive are games planned for the USA then cancelled. Things that immediately come to mind is Maui Mallard in Cold Shadow - an NTSC version of the Sega Genesis version exists with improvements and changes, but Nintendo secured exclusivity for the game in that region, so that ended up releasing only in Brazil.

A Daze in Christmas was also formally cancelled after being rushed for release, but some copies were already ordered for manufacturing so they ended up selling them in Australia anyways.

>>9559062
There's a weird sub-series on the GBA and DS by Takara Tomy that Nintendo of Europe picked publishing for halfway through the series and pretended one of those game was the first in the series, but the "European Version".
Then Takara Tomy continued to release the next games with the wrong order in Europe as "European Versions", and somehow Europe ended up with a game that never got released in the USA (but the localization quality was horrible, Terranigma tier fonts and SNK quality translations)

>>9570083
Nah, the USA got the first game.
I'll explain.

IE1 (DS) and IE3 (DS) are Japan exclusive
Europe got IE2 (DS) twice, the first time was called IE1 with the story/moves swapped with the second game's campaign mode. That's why the Layton team isn't present.

IE1, IE2, IE3 were remade true to their original gameplay/content, for the 3DS.
This collection never released in the West intact, but some parts of it did as standalone games:
IE3 (3DS) was Europe exclusive as usual
IE1 (3DS) was America exclusive digital release, with the European loc poorly copy pasted and referencing IE2 content.
IE2 (3DS) was cancelled alongside Go Galaxy.

I love my Saturn and my DC, but not only do I think both of them are somewhat iffy controls I also actively dislike the Saturn 3d controller.

I only got into DC in the mid 2000s. it's functional though, and it doesn't feel like my hands are resisting actively fleeing from it.

the Saturn controller on the other hand doesn't seem like it was made for human hands to grasp, it feels like grabbing a cereal bowl. also I've never really felt like the analog stick was comfy--maybe it's just me, but even with my large hands it always feels like pushing all the way up on it is overextending my thumb, or at least forcing my hand into a strange position, and the sheer travel distance on the thing just ends up feeling like a lot of wasted effort. >>9569323
I'll try my best to explain what the fuck is really going on here.

One year before Metroid's release in 1985 the Dirty Pair television series aired on Japanese TV. During this time period science fiction in general was experiencing a boom on account of Return of the Jedi releasing just a few years prior.

Samus's helmet and her profession, intergalactic bounty hunter, were clearly inspired by Boba Fett. (Just one of the many references, like Ridley being named after the director of Aliens.)

As for her unarmored form, it was inspired by Yuri from Dirty Pair, a series whose popularity at the time could not be overstated. Dirty Pair was everywhere during that time period and had many copycats and references. In fact, Time Gal, lifts the design wholesale.

But Samus's unarmored form was only really supposed to be an easter egg for players skilled enough to complete the game in time. There wasn't much more thought to it beyond that and its design was based on the most popular female design of the time period.

Most people weren't even aware that Samus was female until the late 90s. They just assumed the person you played as was a guy.

The author of this article seems to have done more actual research into this than anyone:
https://www.acriticalhit.com/metroids-justin-bailey-is-a-real-person-heres-why-he-hasnt-spoken-up/

His conclusion is that Justin Bailey was probably a random player of the game who input their own name for the hell of it, followed by a row of dashes, and it JUST HAPPENED to register as a functional password with a bunch of shit unlocked, including the New Game+ alternate suit.

This seems like a rather remarkable set of coincidences, these games usually have some sort of checksum integrated into the password so inputting just anything won't work, and the fact this just happens to work with two six-character names and a row of plain dashes should be investigated to see just how likely any random password--no, not random, any password containing names and aesthetic repeating characters--is to be both valid and full of ingame goodies. Then, you'd have to have this mysterious Justin Bailey kid sending a letter to some gaming mag about the great password, but neglect to mention that it's actually his own name, or the magazine reprints it without this information and "makes up" the "just in bailey" rumor. The author suggests the "real" "Justin Bailey" may have been a 2-year old child at the time and a friend or family member just tried every name they new until one registered. All seems kinda sus IMO.

>>9580484
You can change the palette in emulators. NES only had composite and RF video outputs, so there's a debate of what NES colors are "supposed" to look like. Some people the garish colors of the PC10 is the definitive palette while others thing the duller hours of composite are the real deal. Just look for a palette you like.

The switch version is how it’s supposed to look, the vibrant colours are often used to create different colours on composite

Another thing while unrelated but similar situation is audio
Higher kHz audio range often makes the older games sound really tinny, when they were supposed to be lower range, this happened a lot with arcade games

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I love my megadrive but I really don't understand how people can say this is better than lttp. The puzzles, combat or exploration never hits the same quality as lttp. Take basic swordplay for example. The hitbox is dodgy, the swing is slow and enemies don't get knocked back. Enemies also have invuln frames so using your sword as a sword feels plain awful and you end up boomeranging it most of the time. The game has some cool sub weapons/abilities in the form of animals but you can only equip two while the cheetah and the sword swing speed up one are basically mandatory if you want your controls to be somewhat palatable so you hardly ever get to use the others. I feel like you have to be ignoring all of great mechanics and design of lttp to claim this is better. For me personally Story of Thor/Beyond Oasis is a better Zelda competitor while also being a much more unique game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think most of you know how these threads work, but for those that don't I'll explain, you pretty much make a 3x3 grid with your 9 favorite video games of all time, that's the basic idea at least, though some people make 4x4 or even 5x5 grids, some use the cover arts while others use promotional art of fan art, some write the details of each item on the front, such as name and year of release, and others simply let the cover do all of the information talk. Well, regardless of how you all prefer to do it, I think it's always quite fun to see what everyone's into, how their tastes may be similar to mine, or very different, but most of all it's a thread to show what gave us good memories.

I made mine on GIMP, but here are some sites you may use as a template.
https://www.befunky.com/create/collage/
https://topsters.org/
https://bighugelabs.com/mosaic.php

Well, I'll start the thread with my own 3x3, which I know might look odd, but it's because I decided to make some rules for myself instead of just choosing my 9 favorites, the idea was to have only a single installment per franchise, and a single choice per console, while also trying to include only those that I've either completed 100%, if there is any sort of completion system, and/or beat in the most difficult setting, if there are difficulty settings to choose from, this way I essentially turned the 3x3 into a game itself, a puzzle. In the end I had to cheat a little and include a couple of Sonic installments, but one of them is focused on Tails, and is a MetroidVania, so I think it's fine.

Play it. The Suikoden series has a save transfer system, so unlocking all of the characters in 1 will give you more party members in 2, having that full roster in 2 will unlock more shit in 3. etc.

Bear in mind that you should play the games in NTSC format. Not because of the usual PAL slowdown (all Suikoden games on the PS2 released in Europe come with a PAL60 option), but because they went full retard and never released Suikoden 3 in PAL regions, even though both 4 and 5 got an official release.

And honestly I'd recommend a guide for them games, some of the requirements for recruiting certain characters are pants on head retarded and you'd get pissed off after finishing a game only to realize that you've missed somebody so your playthrough of the series will never be complete.

Tropical regions abound with biodiversity due to the greater influx of energy, resulting in higher populations with higher metabolisms. They reproduce quickly, die quickly and therefore evolve quickly. Polar regions are the opposite; the flora and fauna there can live for centuries and therefore have fewer chances to evolve.

The AAA game landscape has become more "polar" with each new generation. It's not just maturing technology, games evolve slower because all the money and effort are going to a handful of games with massive lifecycles. Fewer studios throwing their own ideas into the mix.

If Destiny 1 came out now instead of 2014, would it feel dated in any way but visually?

You just have to look at film to see how we classify movies as "retro/classics". Basically, Quentin Tarantino movies from the 90s will never be seen the same way as some Historical epics from the 1950s. Terminator to now is the same distance as Terminator to Gone with the Wind.

You'll have extensive focus on transitional era games, like Final Fantasy VII for JRPGs and Halo for popularizing First Person shooters on consoles. Being the first important or popular game in the genre will be seen as more important than being "good" imo.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9566482
Everything before Awakening is consistently pretty solid, and even the games that came afterwards are generally not bad from a gameplay perspective. The first 5 games in the series, all developed by Shouzou Kaga, introduce wildly new mechanics that are sometimes totally unique to that respective entry, which leads to the gameplay feeling a lot more fresh to me than the entries developed after his departure from nintendo in the late 90s. While some of these later titles are legitimately great games, they all play more or less exactly the same, with the main source of variation being the map design and character skills. By the way, Kaga's game Berwick Saga is probably the best take on that form of SRPG and is a masterpiece, the only titles that really come close to it in the FE series for me are 4 and 5.

No. Not at all. In fact it was literally the 180 degree turning point for the Leisure Suit Larry games going from "mature, comedic, and cleverly written adventure" games, to "cheap, hokey, bargain bin trash".

Leisure Suit Larry 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, and even 7 to a limited degree are all regarded as classic adventure game titles, some of them even among the best. Magna Cum Laude was an embarrassment and a last-ditch effort to try and cash in on their fame with a quick buck, rather than creating a good adventure game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9568521
It's a long story anon, but it's an old urban legend of the internet that most likely started the "creepy pasta" fad. Basically, the joke of the day back in 1989 was that the Leisure Suit Larry series was finished. At the end of LSL3, he gets a job literally working for Sierra and lives in a log cabin with his wife. The end. Then there were some firings at Sierra that year of a couple notable individuals (who will not be mentioned, for fear of internet-sleuths finding me out), who were caught having a seance in the backrooms of the offices at 3:33 AM. Al Lowe, who was a practicing Methodist at the time, demanded they be fired. Shortly after, Sierra wanted a sequel to Leisure Suit Larry 3, which Al Lowe refused to do. Until a series of unfortunate misshaps occurred. According to sources, Al Low slept in one day an hour later than usual. When he tried to get ready to go to work and hurried out the door, he saw a piano had fallen on his car. The next week, on a busride back from the office, a man held the driver of the bus at knife point and almost stabbed Lowe, until a plain-clothes policeman arrested the would-be attacker. Bad shit continued to happen, and eventually Al Lowe decided he was getting someone upstairs angry for not using his talents, so began work on LSL4.

That's where the fun stuff begins. Almost immediately following the development of the coding for the game, it repeatedly had to be redone, as the code constantly got corrupted over and over again. Art assets would unknowingly disappear. Apparently late one night, Al Lowe stated he heard faint whisperings in the office and was so skeeved out he refused to work late nights anymore. He also heard tell of a man in black who would arrive in the office lobby, before anyone was at the office, when the doors were locked, at 5 AM on the dot for 2 weeks straight. In the end, the project collapsed as Al Lowe refused any further work on the project.

>>9574513
>Any that had it as the default?

Sin and Punishment was conceived to utilize it.
From Iwata Asks, Sin and Punishment: Star Successor:

>Maegawa: All right. It all began with the Nintendo 64 controller. At the time Nintendo had suggested two ways of holding it, left position and right position, but most games called for the right position.
>Iwata: Super Mario 64 used the right position, so everyone used that.
>Maegawa: We started talking about how no one hardly ever used the left position, even though you can perform independent actions with it.
>Iwata: You can do some unique controls, but no one used it.
>Maegawa: Right, no one used it. But we thought it would make for interesting game operation and started development.
>Iwata: So Sin & Punishment began with you deciding to make full use of the left position.
>Maegawa: Yes. We thought maybe you could aim with the analog stick and move with the D-pad in the left position.
>Iwata: How did that work out as you began development?
>Maegawa: We realized that the independent operations in the left position would be unexpectedly hard for players the first time they tried it.
>Iwata: Because they'd never done it before.

https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/wii/sinandpunishment/0/0/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9574740
>Sega would have been extremely gun-shy about releasing any kind of power add-on for the Dreamcast.
They're retarded enough to try this sort of shit again.
But depending on pricing it could work.
They did plan for this anyway, the DC has rails on the bottom made for this. That pic is an extension for a working zip support prototype, that's a normal DC on top of it.
It wouldn't be far fetched to believe they had other plans including increasing the console's power if the thing was successful and needed it
Because how else would the DC run VF4? VF was a huge deal for Sega back then and they would port it on console no matter what the cost.
If not for more power, they would need to downgrade it by a lot if they were to port it on the base Dreamcast, even more than the PS2 version. The naomi 2 basically double the naomi/DC CPU/GPU + a transform and lightning graphic chip. I think a DC expansion pack could do with just adding another GPU and the T/L chip and some more ram.
The console was already cheap to produce in the first place so by the time Sega would feel the need to add more power to the console in say 2002-2003, those chips would be already 5 year old.
It's just a fun theory I think about sometimes, but I think it could have worked. IIRC there were rumors about this back then.

I had the similar history with this game.

I tried to play it for the first time some 15-18 years ago and I didn't get it, I barely made it past the intro. I tried again some 5 years later and went further along the game but quickly got bored, again.

It's only in the recent years that I enjoyed it. I fell in like with Dragon Quest, following that I played Earthbound Beginnings which I adored. After beating that, I finally playthrough through Earthbound and enjoyed it, but coming from the first game it's a huge disappointment.
There are many things in the second game that are there "just so it is like the first game", such as the whole melody thing, except it doesn't fit in Earthbound and doesn't have an explanation. The first game also had more freedom, more exploration, and more importantly, more challenge, which is why Earthbound was still a disappointment.
However, the first game lacked in dungeons and in actual bosses (starting half way through the game, you're given a freebie against every boss, and they're not numerous to begin with). In comparison the second game shined in that regard: many and varied dungeons, many bosses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Maybe it's because I didn't wait so long to play this game (though I still played it rather late in relation to when it was released). Although I'm not the kind of person to let others influence what I should like or not, positively or negatively, but I should mention I'm not the biggest RPG fan or non-action games in general (though I did enjoy some classic ones like Dragon Quest III).
I don't know what people like OP expect from this game, but I was pleased with Earthbound: seeing enemies on the map and even being able to sneak behind them/instakill weaker enemies was a pretty welcome change from most other RPGs, that alone made me enjoy it more than most.
The HP rolling mechanic made the turn based menu combat somewhat a bit more dynamic than in other games, too.
The limited inventory was, I think, clever on the dev's parts as it encourages actually spending items instead of hoarding like a scrub.
I actually played this game because of Keiichi Suzuki's music, as I love his band Moonriders and his other many music projects, he's a legend. And Shigesato Itoi's writing is also a nice condiment.
I was also drawn in by the simple, colorful art direction, it's very quintessential 16-bit.
Again not sure what people like OP expect, but I thought it was above average for sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What EB did good:
>enemy encounters visible on the map instead of random encounters means you can actually tell if you need to heal before you reach an exit or not
>also allows you to see new enemies in areas before you fight them
>rolling HP counters allow for recovery from fatal attacks if you can get some healing in fast enough, adding a rare sense of urgency to turn-based combat
>sister's storage system is a direct upgrade from normal item bank systems, since it can be accessed anywhere you can find a phone
>phones acting as save points and item storage access points means you have frequent access to both, including inside of dungeons
>L-button acting as a 2nd A button allows you to play mostly one-handed for easy grinding or walking around and talking to NPCs
>auto-win mechanic speeds up grinding since you don't have to fight weak enemies at all
>built-in optional hint system for new players to prevent them from getting stuck
What EB did bad:
>condiment system might as well not exist, better to have a full load of healing items instead of half a load of slightly buffed healing items
>prayer might as well not exist, since Paula's attack magic is far more reliable and less dangerous to the party
>pizza delivery serves no point, since you can buy better healing items without having to wait
>homesickness mechanic is pure tedium and only serves to slow the game down
>combat direction encounter system is rarely used as on paper, instead it's mostly grey head-on encounters, the rare red when caught while trying to run away, and the green against weaker enemies that run away and you corner
>last half of the game has a lot of backtracking, and the final area is just a level check with a healing/save point so you can grind until you can pass it
>mushroom status has annoying interface screw effect on map which just slows things down
>bicycle is completely worthless the moment you get Paula until you drop her off at home at the end of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
